answer_html: We used the substitution u = 0 and u(5\(\pi\)/2) = sin(\(\pi\)/4) = \(\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}\) from part (a).
answer_latex:
We used the substitution \emph{u} = 0 and \emph{u}(5$\pi$/2)
= \emph{sin}($\pi$/4) = $\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}$ from
{part
(a)}.
hints_html:
For a continuous random variable X with probability density function f(x) the probability that an event a \(\leq\) X \(\leq\) b happens is

\[\begin{aligned} \text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
For a continuous random variable ''X'' with probability density function ''f(x)'' the probability that an event ''a'' &le; ''X'' &le; ''b'' happens is

:<math> \text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f(x)\,dx. </math>
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
A student takes at most 5\(\pi\)/2 minutes to complete the question if his completion time is anywhere between 0 and 5\(\pi\)/2. Hence the probability we are looking for is

\[\begin{aligned} \text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) &= \int_a^b f(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^{5\pi/2} \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} 3u^2\,du \\ &= \left.u^3\right|_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} \\ &= \frac1{2\sqrt{2}}.\end{aligned}\]

We used the substitution u = sin(x/10), du = 1/10 cos(x/10), so that u(0) = 0 and u(5\(\pi\)/2) = sin(\(\pi\)/4) = \(\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}\) from part (a).
sols_latex:
A student takes at most 5$\pi$/2 minutes to complete the question if his
completion time is anywhere between 0 and 5$\pi$/2. Hence the probability we
are looking for is

\begin{align*}
\text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) &= \int_a^b f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{5\pi/2} \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} 3u^2\,du \\
&= \left.u^3\right|_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} \\
&= \frac1{2\sqrt{2}}.
\end{align*}

We used the substitution \emph{u} = \emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10), \emph{du} =
1/10 \emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10), so that \emph{u}(0) = 0 and \emph{u}(5$\pi$/2)
= \emph{sin}($\pi$/4) = $\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}$ from
{part
(a)}.
sols_raw:
A student takes at most 5&pi;/2 minutes to complete the question if his completion time is anywhere between 0 and 5&pi;/2. Hence the probability we are looking for is

:<math> \begin{align}
\text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) &= \int_a^b f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{5\pi/2} \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} 3u^2\,du \\
&= \left.u^3\right|_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} \\
&= \frac1{2\sqrt{2}}.
\end{align}
</math>

We used the substitution ''u'' = ''sin''(''x''/10), ''du'' = 1/10 ''cos''(''x''/10), so that ''u''(0) = 0 and ''u''(5&pi;/2) = ''sin''(&pi;/4) = <math>\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}</math> from [http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2005/Question_7_(a) part (a)].
statement_html:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable whose probability density function is

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\ 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

(b) What is the probability that a student will take less than \(5\pi/2\) minutes to complete the problem?
statement_raw:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable whose probability density function is

:<math> f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases} </math>

(b) What is the probability that a student will take less than <math>5\pi/2</math> minutes to complete the problem?
